posts.name: Pat
posts.cooked:
Our robot has 4 MK4i swerve modules with a cancoder on each module for the turning. The angle offsets for each cancoder are correctly loaded when the robot starts up, and the robot drives fine.

However, after driving in teleop and performing auto routines for a certain period, one of the modules (back right) seems to randomly lose its alignment from the other wheels and stays at an incorrect, random angle. Then, as we drive in teleop after testing our auto, by going forwards and backwards the robot turns slightly and the wheels are getting continually off the desired angle (the most recent test we had the front right and back left become skewed). So there seems to be some disconnect with our desired wheel position.

We have redone the angle offsets for each module’s cancoder several times to no avail. We have checked the cancoder itself and its solder connections are fine. All of the CAN IDs for each cancoder are correctly assigned. The magnet in the module is superglued and secure. We installed a CANivore yesterday with all of the cancoders, swerve motors, and Pigeon 2 gyro on its network to reduce our CAN utilization.  We are thinking there might be a delay or something between the canivore and our drive code causing the intended absolute positions and the offsets to deviate.

While the issue was occurring with the back right module, we disabled the robot and manually turned the wheel to the correct position, and the angle offset for the back right module is the same as its original value as defined in the code, but the issue persists until we manually realign the wheels while the robot is off; even if we redeploy code or power cycle the issue persists. We have found that the messed up wheel is offset the initial angle offset value, i.e. the initial angle offset value of the back right encoder is roughly 270 degrees and the back right module is 270 degrees “off” from the rest of the wheels. Here is a link to our (messy) code:

barbecue bacon burger. Contribute to FRC3950/ChargedUp2023 development by creating an account on GitHub.

Our drivetrain code and constants are in the Constants.java, SwerveModule.java file and the Swerve.java file.

Our competition starts tomorrow. nbd

posts.name: Josh Buker
posts.cooked:
[I am not entirely sure if this solution will fix your problem, but may be worth a shot]…

We were also having an issue with one of our back wheels randomly deciding to not follow the CANCoder values.

The solution that seems to have worked is running the resetToAbsolute method (from the swerve / drivetrain subsystem) within the Robot.autonomousInit method. If you are testing in shop and not running auto, you can also slap it in teleop init.

Pretty much what was happening is the motors grab their initial value from the CANCoder since it is an absolute value compared to the relative encoders in the wheels (At least for our NEO’s). The problem was the CANCoder’s weren’t fully booted up before the swerve modules tried to grab the value, so it defaulted to the default value of the motor with the offset applied (May explain why your offset is 270 and it was off by 270 degrees). Which from your reference of a delay, sounds like you guys already suspected this.

One thing you can also test is connecting that method to a button so if it ever happens during testing or a match, you can press that button, and re-seed the motor encoders to realign everything properly.

I hope this works, and if not, that it will give a new perspective on the problem that could lead to finding the necessary fix.

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked:
For a drive straight in auto function we used an arcade-style for our swerve using the WPILib arcadeIK method. Sometimes the robot veered and a back wheel was “dragging” at about 90 deg (could be 270) out of kilter while the other 3 were straight at 0/180 degrees.

Didn’t happen often enough to track down and I attributed it to being at an edge case of full power on one side and 0 power on the other side. (We use essentially the WPILib SwerveBot example to drive.) I avoided that case and I never found anything amiss with any code. Don’t know if it’s fixed but it didn’t appear to happen in competition.

posts.name: Stephen Peroni
posts.cooked: Thank you both. We will try this tomorrow morning for practice day.

posts.name: Alex
posts.cooked: Id love to know if this resolves the issue.

posts.name: WarrenR
posts.cooked:
Check the steering belt.  You may find that some of the teeth have been stripped off the belt.  This was a problem for us at our regional last weekend.  Everything checked out when the robot was up on trolley.  The wheels were all free. they turned and rotated without issue.  That was because there was no back pressure on the belt.

The driver keep complaining about the robot pulling to one side and we keep testing everything OK.

Eventually we discovered the issue by trying to rotate the wheels while applying some resistance to the steering motor pinion.

I believe this problem is more like to occur if you are running the 9mm belt instead of the 15mm belt.  The 9 mm belt comes from upgrading a Mk4 kit to a Mk4i with the upgrade pack.

We had a swerve module die last year (NB:It was our fault for leaving out a bearing) and it cost us two matches in the qualifications because it took us that long to get it sorted.  This time round we were prepared as we had a spare module ready to go with a single multi connection plug. We were able to swap the module, ID the motors and CANCoder and adjust the absolute offset on the CANCoder in a 4 match window without missing a match.  Well done 6508 pit crew.

posts.name: Stephen Peroni
posts.cooked: We’ll check this too… we did get the 4i kit so I believe we have the correct belt.  Another thing to keep an eye on.

posts.name: Arnav T
posts.cooked:
We’re having the identical issue of one module dragging and we’ve attempted to move resetToAbsolute in all the suggested locations and our swerve drivetrain nearly always runs fine, but occasionally during testing we run into that one module dragging and have no idea why. It’s not common at all and there’s very little we see in common between the times where the swerve modules work properly and when they don’t.

Running resetToAbsolute in robotInit seemed to help this a bit for us. Also the waitForCanCoder function in Swerve.java suggested in the thread linked below helped a bit too.

Thread: After restarting the Robot We need to re align the wheels at the start · Issue #8 · Team364/BaseFalconSwerve · GitHub Our codebase: GitHub - BobcatRobotics/2023-ChargedUp-177 at wne

We will try checking the steering belt though next time we meet.

link_counts.title: After restarting the Robot We need to re align the wheels at the start · Issue #8 · Team364/BaseFalconSwerve · GitHub

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked:
There are enough comments about dragging a wheel that we should try to add to the science of swerve with some sort of self-checking swerve code and reporting on problems such as this.

What’s frustrating is I’d think the profiled PID controller typical of steering wheels should be self-correcting. And for sure every 20ms a new absolute setting is sent so why wouldn’t the wheels be turned right no matter how screwy they were the iteration before?

The comments on a wheel being turned roughly 90/180 degrees from where it should be points to a potential problem with the optimize turn method failing on an edge case. Maybe it’s time to instrument that method. But again, why wouldn’t it self-correct within 20ms?

Another thought from other posts is the CANcode is failing to the 270 degree direction. Since our failures were when driving straight down field 180/0 degrees, a failure of the CANcoder with it registering 270 would give the 90 deg out of whack dragging wheel. Some sort of reset makes everything work okay again so the CANcoder couldn’t be permanently broken. Maybe CTRE like @bhall-ctre or @ozrien have some insight into how this could happen. I can’t find the post to refresh my memory describing the CANcoder being at 270 degrees.

posts.name: Omar Zrien CTR-Electronics Co-owner
posts.cooked:
SLAB-Mr.Thomas:

Maybe CTRE like @bhall-ctre or @ozrien have some insight into how this could happen. I can’t find the post to refresh my memory describing the CANcoder being at 270 degrees.

Use case-wise, we see these typical usecases with swerve azimuth.

Teams seeding Talons with CANcoders once (Phoenix 5)

Teams using remote CANcoder (Phoenix 5 or Phoenix Pro), so Talon just uses last CANcoder value automatically when CANcoder publishes.  So no seeding necessary but the sensor bandwidth is limited by the CANcoder update rate.

Teams using fused CANcoder (Phoenix Pro)  - where Talon fuses its internal sensor with external CANcoder.  This means no seeding and you get high bandwidth sensor data (best of both worlds).

In the circumstances we’ve seen in our support calls / emails, the issues are typically

teams using CANcoder’s getPosition() when they really mean to call getAbsolutePosition()

Calling the getter once inside a constructor, which can fail because our library has just loaded / CAN frames have not been received yet.  Check return getLastError/getLastTimeStamp appropriately to ensure fresh data.

not handling when a talon breaker-resets, which can be detected via API or self-test.

physical issue, slippage, magnet out of field, etc.

forgetting to apply correct sensor offsets, either thru configs or locally.  In the case of configs, make sure to check return codes so you know configs are successful.

The first three tend to only happen with use case 1, since the use case 2 and 3 recover automatically via the remote/fusion strategies.

posts.name: Matt
posts.cooked:
We are seeding Falcons once using absolute encoders and we use logic from 254 to basically not start the entire bot unless our CANCoders have loaded.

We have still had this issue and it is ALWAYS that the magnet slipped. We super glue them in, but occasionally they seem to slip and then we have to re-glue them. We think it is just that we never did it good enough the first time, because we have now run an entire comp without an issue.

I would 100% check that the magnet is secured if you have all of the other things identified by @ozrien taken care of.

Edit: to check this we just take the CANCoder off and then use something metal to try to pull out the magnet. If it comes out, there is a problem

Below is the hack I mentioned from 254 ( FRC-2022-Public/Robot.java at 6a24236b37f0fcb75ceb9d5dec767be58ea903c0 · Team254/FRC-2022-Public · GitHub and FRC-2022-Public/Cancoders.java at main · Team254/FRC-2022-Public (github.com) ):

posts.name: Stephen Peroni
posts.cooked:
CoolBudy1:

resetToAbsolute method (from the swerve / drivetrain subsystem) within the Robot.autonomousInit method. If you are testing in shop and not running auto, you can also slap it in teleop init.

we put this method in auto init and teleop init and ran the whole regional without an issue.  That seems to resolve the issue.  Thank you so so much for the suggestion!

posts.name: Josh Buker
posts.cooked: Glad to hear it worked and I hope your regional went well!
